drawer.InformationforwhencallinganAmbulance: Information for when calling an Ambulance

home.title: Home
home.emergencyText: Call for help immediately in case of emergency

emergency.title: Emergency
emergency.conscious: The person is unconscious! Please call emergency services immediately.
emergency.unconscious: The person is conscious. Keep him calm and give first aid.
emergency.bystander: or ask a bystander to call

heart_attack.pain: Pain below jawline above belly button
heart_attack.nitrate: Take Sorbitrate/Nitrate under tongue every 5 mins (max 3 times)
heart_attack.aspirin: Dissolve Aspirin in water and take
heart_attack.smallAttack: Small attack: max up to 6 attacks
heart_attack.disprin: Disprin - 325mg (Mouth chewable or dissolve in water)
heart_attack.breath: If breaths are not possible, give only chest compressions

cprGuide.repeat: Repeat the cycle until help arrives
cprGuide.breathNotPossible: If breaths are not possible, give only chest compressions

aimsOfFirstAid.firstAidDefinition: First Aid is the act of providing initial assistance to the injured or ill, prior to handing over to trained personnel.
aimsOfFirstAid.washHands: Wash hands before and after treating a patient, and wear first aid gloves
aimsOfFirstAid.useSterileDressings: Use sterile dressings, swabs and one-use disposable items
aimsOfFirstAid.cleanArea: Clean surrounding area with diluted antiseptics or saline
aimsOfFirstAid.rescueBreaths: If providing Rescue Breaths use a CPR Face Shield / Pocket Mask.
aimsOfFirstAid.history: History: What's happened? Accident or illness type obtained from scene, patient, or bystanders.
aimsOfFirstAid.signs: Signs: What can you see? Look for bleeding, bruising, or deformities etc.
aimsOfFirstAid.symptoms: Symptoms: What the patient tells you e.g. pain or how they feel.
aimsOfFirstAid.callForHelp: You are not expected to know everything, so call for help as soon as possible.
aimsOfFirstAid.basicSteps: Even big incidents are just a series of basic first aid steps.

PatientCare.patient_care_desc: Good patient care is one of the most important skills at your disposal. The ability to interact with your patient calmly and confidently will have a positive effect.
PatientCare.patient_care_talking: By simply talking to your patient you can lower anxiety and build trust. Rescuers that become technical, distance themselves from patients.
PatientCare.patient_care_intro: You should introduce yourself in an informal way, e.g. "Hi, I'm Mark. I'm a first aider. Can I help?" This shows the patient that you are able to help, as well as seeking their consent to you providing them with first aid.
PatientCare.patient_care_eye_contact: Maintaining eye contact and talking at the same eye level helps to build trust and confidence. If your patient is sitting, then crouch or sit in front of them.
PatientCare.patient_care_limitations: If you are not a doctor or nurse, you are only able to offer First Aid from what you know or have been taught. Basic First Aid is often about using your common sense; never take anything for granted. Always seek advice from a healthcare professional and call an Ambulance for all persons that need ongoing treatment.
PatientCare.patient_care_example: For example, at the scene of a traffic accident persons travelling in a vehicle may appear to look OK but may be suffering from shock or an injury which is not obvious.
PatientCare.patient_care_thanks: We would like to take this opportunity to thank you for choosing to protect yourself and others. We certainly hope that this App will assist you to confidently help someone in need. We recommend that everyone undertake an accredited first aid course.
PatientCare.patient_care_contact: Dial 112 or visit https://nhm.gov.in/ for your nearest training provider.

ambulance_info.ambulance_info_title: Information for when calling an ambulance
ambulance_info.ambulance_info_desc2: Street number, street name, nearest intersection
ambulance_info.ambulance_info_desc3: Any other direction that may help
ambulance_info.ambulance_info_desc4: Brief overall description of what occurred
ambulance_info.ambulance_info_desc5: Number of people that may need assistance
ambulance_info.ambulance_info_desc8: Give your phone number and be last to hang up

epipen.epipen_step1: Lay the person flat or sitting if breathing is difficult
epipen.epipen_step2: Remove the Epipen‚Äôs blue safety release
epipen.epipen_step3: Place the orange needle into the outer mid thigh
epipen.epipen_step4: Push firmly so it clicks and hold for 3 seconds
epipen.epipen_step5: Release and record the time of the injection
epipen.epipen_step7: Start Timer. If no improvement after 5 minutes, give a second injection with another pen.

bandages.bandages_medium_hospital_crepe_desc: Soft strapping and wrapping providing gentle support and wound cover.
bandages.bandages_heavy_crepe_size: On limbs ideally use the 10cm size (the size of a fist)
bandages.bandages_heavy_crepe_instruction: Apply evenly at the correct pressure without creasing
bandages.bandages_triangular_use: Used for Arm Slings / Padding / Strapping
bandages.bandages_cohesive_desc: Self adhesive (i.e. it grips onto itself)
bandages.bandages_cohesive_use: For use in sports injury and veterinary use
bandages.bandages_wound_dressings_no13: NO13 Small Combine Dressing on 5cm cotton bandage
bandages.bandages_wound_dressings_no14: NO14 Medium Combine Dressing on 7.5cm cotton bandage
bandages.bandages_wound_dressings_no15: NO15 Large Combine Dressing on 10cm cotton bandage
bandages.bandages_wound_dressings_use: Used for open wounds and ideal for eye injury (No13 as the preferred size).

FirstAidHomeData.BITES_STINGS_BEES_WASPS_HORNETS_ANTS: Bites & Stings - Bees, Wasps, Hornets, Ants
FirstAidHomeData.BITES_STINGS_RED_BACK_OTHER_SPIDERS: Bites & Stings - Red Back and Other Spiders
FirstAidHomeData.BITES_STINGS_SNAKE_FUNNEL_WEB: Bites & Stings - Snake Bite or Funnel Web Spider
FirstAidHomeData.CHOKING: What to do in case of Feeling of Suffocation

Management.title: Management
Management.CareSeveredPart: Take very important care of the severed part
Management.EmergencyCall: Or ask a bystander to call 000

ManagementOfStump.title: Management Of Stump
ManagementOfStump.ElevateStump: Elevate the stump and apply pressure with padding such as Triangular Bandages or towels strapped firmly with crepe or compression bandages.
ManagementOfStump.ReassurePatient: Give reassurance to the patient and monitor until trained personnel arrive.

ManagementOfBodyPart.title: Management Of Body Part
ManagementOfBodyPart.PlaceInBag: Place amputated part into a zip-sealed bag or sealed container.
ManagementOfBodyPart.SurroundWithIce: Place a towel over a container of icy water to surround the part, without making direct contact with the ice.
ManagementOfBodyPart.NoDirectIceContact: NEVER allow the body part to come into direct contact with the ice as this can result in frostbite and damage to the tissue.
ManagementOfBodyPart.NoWashUnlessChemical: NEVER wash the severed part unless chemicals have caused contamination. Get advice by phone.

allergies_anaphylaxis.title: ALLERGIES ANAPHYLAXIS
allergies_anaphylaxis.description: Allergic reactions, although usually localised, can become life-threatening. Act quickly and calmly.
allergies_anaphylaxis.desc: In many cases, the patient will be fully aware of the treatment required as well as carry the medication needed to relieve their symptoms. It is important to recognise this and facilitate patient‚Äôs requests.

symptoms.sym7: Mottled skin with possible swollen areas

askBystander.call: Or ask a bystander to call 000

conscious.cons1: Reassure the patient, help into a comfortable position, and minimise their movement
conscious.cons2: Loosen any clothing from around the neck
conscious.cons3: If applicable, assist patient to use their Adrenalin Auto-injector (Epipen)
conscious.cons4: Remove any restrictive items, i.e rings, watches or belts

unconscious.uncon2: Loosen any clothing from the patient‚Äôs neck

asthma.title: ASTHMA
asthma.description: Episodes can occur for no apparent reason,allergies,even weather, people active in sport or nervous tension .
asthma.desc: In many cases, the patient will be fully aware of the treatment required as well as carry the medication needed to relieve their symptoms. It is important to recognise this and facilitate patient‚Äôs requests.

symptoms.sym4: In Severe cases: Exhaustion, distressed, fighting for breath

askBystander.call: Or ask a bystander to call 000

conscious.cons2: Help to sit upright, learning forward onto a table, and support with a cushion
conscious.cons5: if no improvement then call an Ambulance

askBystander.call: Or ask a bystander to call 000

conscious.cons1: Reassure the patient, help into a comfortable position, and minimise their movement
conscious.cons2: Loosen any clothing from around the neck
conscious.cons3: If applicable, assist patient to use their Adrenalin Auto-injector (Epipen)
conscious.cons4: Remove any restrictive items, i.e rings, watches or belts

unconscious.uncon2: Loosen any clothing from the patient‚Äôs neck

VitalSign.title: VITAL SIGNS
VitalSign.description: Recording patient's vital signs will assist in the handover to the ambulance, paramedics or emergency nursing staff.
VitalSign.desc: Recording vital signs every 10 minutes provides the rescuer with an early record of the patient's mental status, pulse, breathing rate, skin colour, temperature and condition. Giving this information to medical staff could dramatically improve the speed of treatment and patient recovery.

signs.mentalStatus: Mental status: conscious, drowsy or unconscious
signs.pulse: Pulse: taken with your finger not thumb
signs.breathing: Breathing: count their breaths for one minute
signs.pupils: Pupils: Pupil size for changes to one or both eyes
signs.skinColor: Skin colour: patient colours and condition
signs.temperature: Temperature: thermometer (ear or under arm is best)
signs.bloodPressure: Blood pressure: best for experience operators

VitalSign.note: Don't refer vital signs in patient's earshot to paramedic or nurse as this may cause panic.

broken_bone_fracture.title: BROKEN BONE OR FRACTURE
broken_bone_fracture.management: Reassure the patient, help into a comfortable position, and minimise their movement.
broken_bone_fracture.management2: Call an ambulance if the injured area is clearly deformed, painful, or transport is needed.

immobilisation.general: Immobilise by strapping above and below the break using bandages and a splint or sling. Check circulation and monitor frequently; watching extremities (fingers and toes) for loss of circulation (loss of skin colour).
immobilisation.fingerToe: Immobilise a finger or toe with a splint or taping / strapping to another.
immobilisation.leg: A leg can be immobilised by strapping to the other leg.

Stroke.title: STROKE

signsSymptoms.title: Signs and Symptoms : THINK FAST
signsSymptoms.face: Face : Is there loss of muscle tone on one side of the face?
signsSymptoms.arms: Arms : Can they raise their arms - is there Paralysis or Weakness to one or both sides of the body?
signsSymptoms.speech: Speech : Is there difficulty speaking or seeing?

emergency.bystanderHelp: Or ask a bystander to call 000

otherSymptoms.heading: They amy
otherSymptoms.sym1: They may become confused and lose control of their bladder and bowel
otherSymptoms.sym2: Their pupil sizes may become unequal
otherSymptoms.sym3: They may start vomiting and often become unconscious

Stroke.moreInfo: Occurs when a patient suffers bleeding into the brain caused by a ruptured blood vessel or a blood clot blocking blood supply. This can result in damaged brain tissues or death. Signs and symptoms may differ according to the area of the brain that is being damaged.

steps.rest_patient: Rest the patient and the injured part
steps.ice_application: Ice the injury site for 20 minutes every 2 hours
steps.elevate_injured_part: Elevate the injured part to reduce swelling

bleeding.title: BLEEDING
bleeding.description: Episodes can occur for no apparent reason, allergies, even weather, people active in sport or nervous tension.

control.ctrl1: When controlling a bleed on a conscious patient, don't be afraid to ask for their help
control.ctrl2: Remember that you only have one pair of hands so they can help to apply pressure and hold dressings while you bandage them. It is also important to allow them to assist if disposable gloves are unavailable, to protect from infection.

bleeding.additionalText: If you don't like the sight of blood then the sooner you dress the better.

askBystander.call: Or ask a bystander to call 000

management.point1: Check for danger and put on disposable gloves (if available)
management.point2: Rest & reassure patient. This can actually slow bleeding
management.point3: Check wound for foriegn objects and remove if not embedded
management.point4: Apply direct pressure to the wound site
management.point5: Elevate the wound to a comfortable position above the heart
management.point6: If bleeding is severe call an Ambulance
management.point7: Apply non-adhesive dressing to wound site, bandage in place
management.point9: If the wound continues to bleed then apply another dressing and bandage to the wound site
management.point10: IMPORTANT DO NOT remove the first dressing and bandage.
management.point11: If unsuccessful, apply pressure and call an Ambulance

nose_bleed.title: Nosebleed
nose_bleed.apply_pressure: With the patient leaning slightly forward, apply direct pressure to the soft part of the nose for at least 10 minutes

bees.title: BITES & STINGS
bees.description: Bee stings can cause pain, swelling, and allergic reactions. In severe cases, they can lead to anaphylaxis, which is life-threatening.

symptoms.sym1: Localised pain, redness, swelling and a possible ache in the groin or under arm.
symptoms.sym2: In cases of severe allergic reaction the patient may also experience swelling of the hands, face and airway.

askBystander.call: Or ask a bystander to call 000

mild.mild1: Remove bee stings by flicking with fingers
mild.mild2: Apply a cold compress to the sting site to reduce pain (don't apply ice or a cold pack directly to the skin, use a cloth pr towel)
mild.mild3: In cases of severe allergic reaction apply compression bandages:
mild.mild4: If Symptoms persist seek medical advice from the poison information Center on 131126 or your doctor

snakeBite.title: BITES & STINGS
snakeBite.subtitle: SNAKE BITE OF FUNNEL WEB SPIDER

steps.step1: Reassure the patient , help into a comfortable position, and minimise their movement
steps.step2: DO NOT wash the venom off of the bite area as the venom may be identifiable later at the hospital
steps.step3: Place a wound dressing over the wound
steps.step4: Bandage over the bite and towards the heart with, if available, with 10cm heavy crepe roller bandage
steps.step5: On a leg, you may use as many as 3 or 4 bandages with the aim of immobilising the limb without affecting circulation
steps.step6: Place a mark on bandage to identify the bite location
steps.step7: WARNING : you must not walk the patient, remove bandages or apply a tourniquet

Redback.title: BITES & STINGS
Redback.description: If a child tells you they have been bitten by a spider, always treat them as though they have been bitten.
Redback.symptomsHeading: Symptoms of a Redback Spider Bite

symptoms.sym6: Aches and pain may continuw for days to weeks

management.manage1: The patient should be reassured and made comfortable, while remaining at rest.
management.manage2: Apply a cold compress to the bite site which will help relieve pain (don't apply ice or a cold pack directly to the skin, use a cloth or towel).
management.manage3: Immobilise arms or legs with slings or splints

funnelspider.title: BITES & STINGS
funnelspider.description: 95% of bites occur on the arms and legs.
funnelspider.subdescription: If children say they have been bitten, believe them and treat accordingly.
funnelspider.subsubdescription: We recommend using 3 x 10cm heavy crepe bandages for snake bites.
funnelspider.typesHeading: SNAKE BITE OR FUNNEL WEB SPIDER

symptoms.sym1: Puncture marks at the bite site

conscious.cons1: Reassure the patient, help them into a comfortable position, and minimize their movement.
conscious.cons2: DO NOT wash the wound as the venom may be identifiable later at the hospital.
conscious.cons3: Place a wound dressing over the wound.
conscious.cons4: Bandage over the bite and towards the heart, if available, with a 10cm heavy crepe roller bandage.
conscious.cons5: On a leg, you may use as many as 3 or 4 bandages with the aim of immobilizing the limb without affecting circulation.
conscious.cons6: Place a mark on the bandage to identify the bite location.
conscious.cons7: WARNING: You must not walk the patient, remove bandages, or apply a tourniquet.

cprGuides.title: CPR
cprGuides.subtitle: RESUSCITATION

cprSendList.step1: Ask a bystander to call for HELP.

airwaySteps.step2: If blocked: roll on side and clear. When clear.

breathingSteps.step1: Look, listen and feel for normal breathing.
breathingSteps.step3: If not normal, start chest compressions

compressionsSteps.step1: Position the heel of one hand in the middle of the patient's chest and grasp the wrist with the other hand (Children up to 2 hands - Infants 2 fingers.
compressionsSteps.step2: Give 30 Chest Compressions to depth of 1/3 and at a rate of 100 to 120 per minute followed by 2 Rescue Breaths.
compressionsSteps.step3: Continue 30 Chest Compressions and 2 rescue breaths until qualified help arrives.

cprGuides.defibrillationText: If available, attach AED (Defibrillator) as soon as possible and follow its prompts.

emergency.bystander: If you are a bystander, call:

Recovery.description: Any Person that is unresponsive and breathing normally should be placed on their side in the lateral Recovery Position.

steps.sym1: Knee next to the patient and place their near arm at right angles to the body
steps.sym2: Lay the patients furthest arm acress their chest and support in place
steps.sym3: Lift the patients furthest knee until their foot is flat on the ground beside the knee of their other leg.
steps.sym4: Whilst supporting the elbow,gently apply pressure to the outside of the bent knww and carefully roll the patient towords you.
steps.sym5: Check that the patient's airway is clear and that they are breathing normally
steps.sym6: If patient's breathing becomes abnormal then return them onto their black and commence.

bitetick.title: Bite and Tick
bitetick.subtitle: Tick
bitetick.description: May be found anywhere on the body especially the more hairy zones..

symptoms.sym1: Irritation .Weakness, Lethargy in swallowing and breathing.

Management.title: Treatment
Management.point2: Squeezing or trying to forcibly remove a tick may cause more tick saliva to be injected.
Management.point3: Tick saliva can cause severe allergic reactions. If you suspect this is the case, call an ambulance and seek urgent medical care.
Management.point4: So, Spray the tick with an Ether Containing Spray. Spray five times from a distance of approx 1cm, then wait a few minutes.
Management.point5: If the tick is still moving or you are insure, Spray another five times and wait a few .

tickemergency.call: Or ask a bystander to call 000

Management.title: Treatment
Management.point1: Protect the rescuer and the patient from the chemical.
Management.point2: Irgently, run cool water over the affected area for a minimum of 20 minutes.
Management.point3: Carefully remove any clothing that has been contaminated by the chemical.
Management.point4: DO NOT remove any clothing that is attached to skin.
Management.point5: Very carefully remove rings or watches, If unsure leave for medical staff to remove.
Management.point6: Cover the affected area with a non-adherent sterile dressing or burnaid impregnated dressing or burnaid gel.
Management.point7: DO NOT break blisters or apply any ointment, butter or powders to the affected area
Management.point8: Always seek urgent medical assistance for all burns

description1.title: Inhalation Burns to Mouth or Throat from Fumes
description1.point1: Suspect an inhalation injury if the face shows signs of burns.
description1.point2: Patient may develop difficulty in breathing with injury to the airway.
description1.point3: Pain and swallowing problems may then occur.

Note.title: Note:
Note.point1: Consult the MSDS(Material Safety Data Sheet) and / or call The National Poisons Information Centre on 131126

conscious.cons1: Give patient reassurance and remove all restrictive clothing and jewellery from around the neck and chest area

Information.title: Information for When calling an ambulance
Information.point3: Any other direction that may help
Information.point4: Brief overall description of what occurred

type.step1: Number of the People that may need assistance
type.step4: Give your phone number and be last to hang up

Management.point1: Remove patient from any fire danger (uowind if outside)
Management.point2: Cool the affected area with cool running water for up to 20 minutes[start timer] (stop if patient shivers)
Management.point3: Carefully remove any clothing that has been burnt or is affected by hot water
Management.point4: DO NOT remove any clothing that is attached to skin
Management.point5: Very carefully remove rings or watches, if unsure leave for medical staff to remove
Management.point6: Cover the affected area with a non-adherent sterile dressing or burnaid gel.
Management.point8: DO NOT break blisters or apply any ointment, butter or powders to the affected area
Management.point9: Always seek urgent medical assistance for all burns

Sunburn.title: Sunburn:
Sunburn.des1: Is just as bad as any other burns, even short periods in the sun can result in serious burns occuring to,back, neck,face, arms or legs.
Sunburn.des2: Medical assistance is most urgent and treatment as stated above with cool running water for up to 20 minutes and then covering with non-adherent dressing is best management.

emergency.bystander: If you are a bystander, call

EffectiveCoughing.Subtitle: MILD Airway Obstruction:
EffectiveCoughing.step1: Continue to monitoe the patient until they recover
EffectiveCoughing.step2: If no improvement, call an Ambulance

conscious.cons1: Give patient reassurance and remove all restrictive clothing and jewellery from around the neck and chest area

DiabeticEmergency.title: DIABETIC EMERGENCY
DiabeticEmergency.description: Diabetes ia a condition caused from a disorder of the pancreas which affects the management of insulin, either not producing enough insulin or not producing insulin at all. This causes the following conditions.
DiabeticEmergency.sym1: Hyperglycaemia : High siger levels in the blood
DiabeticEmergency.sym2: Hypoglycaemia : Low sugar levels in the blood.

Recognition.title: Recognition of Hypergiycaemia (HYPER):
Recognition.Reco3: A 'fruity' smell develops on the breath
Recognition.Reco7: If conscious, assist patient to self administer their own medication
Recognition.Reco8: If unconscious, clear airway and follow the : Basic Life Support Flow Chart:

Recognition2.title: Recognition of Hypoglycaemia (HYPO):
Recognition2.Reco4: May suffer mental confusion and appear aggressive with a drunken appearance
Recognition2.Reco6: Eapid pulse and may become unconscious
Recognition2.Reco7: If conscious, give patient food or drink containing sugar.
Recognition2.Reco8: If unconscious, clear airway and fillow the: Basic Life Support Flow Chart:
Recognition2.Reco9: WARNING: Insulin must not be administered as can be fatal

Concious.title: DIABETIC EMERGENCY
Concious.Subtitle: MANAGEMENT IF CONSCIOUS
Concious.step1: Give the patient jellybeans, a tablespoon of honey, or any drink containing sugar.
Concious.step2: DO NOT give drinks containing saccgarin, sweetener or non sugar

ExposuretoCold.title: EXPOSURE TO COLD
ExposuretoCold.subtitle: HTPERTHERMIA
ExposuretoCold.description: The body temperature only needs to fall by 2¬∞C for HYPOTHERMIA to begin. This may even go unnoticed as the onset is usually grsdual and the recognition of htpothermia is not always easy to detect.

causes.title: Causes:
causes.description: Immersion in cold water, lack of suitable clothing , wind, rain, immobillisation and exhaustion. It often happens to elderly, ill or the unconscious when exposed to low temperature or those living in cold climates with inadequate heating or in adverse weather conditions.

symptoms.sym1: Unusual behaviour with complaints of feeling cold and tired, including confusion and fatigue
symptoms.sym2: May become disturbed with slurred speech
symptoms.sym4: May resist offers of help, possibly resulting in obscene or abusive language.
symptoms.sym5: Shallow weak breathing and a slow pulse may result in falling, collapsing or becoming unresponsive

Management.title: Management
Management.point1: Move the patient to a warm sheltered area protected from the conditions (when moving, be gentle with patient)
Management.point2: Lie the patient flat, remove wet clothing and replace with warm clothing, wrap torso and limbs independently and then as a whole
Management.point3: Cover neck and head leaving the face clear
Management.point4: Insulate patient from the coldness of the ground
Management.point6: If the patient is unresponsive follow the:

HeatExposure.description: ia a far more serious condition than we often believe. Recognising the potential of heat exposure is, by far, the best way of preventing this life threatening situation. All patient experiencing any of the following heat exposure symptoms must receive medical assistance.
HeatExposure.title: Heat Exposure is classified by 3 levels:
HeatExposure.des: Heat Cramps / Heat Exhaustion - sufferers complain of severe muscle pain and cramps, in the legs and abdomen, that may lead to exhaustion i.e faintness, dizziness and weakness.

symptoms.title: Signs and Symptoms:
symptoms.sym6: Then an unconscious state and breathing which becomes noisy.

HeatStrokeConcious.title: EXPOSURE TO HEAT
HeatStrokeConcious.Subtitle: MANAGEMENT IF CONSCIOUS
HeatStrokeConcious.step1: Move the patient to a cool shaded area
HeatStrokeConcious.step2: Remove any additional clothing they may be wearing
HeatStrokeConcious.step3: To assist with heat loss place a cool wet towel on back of neck and forhead. Lie the patient down if possible
HeatStrokeConcious.step4: Call an Ambulance or medical assistance urgently

HeatStrokeUnConcious.title: EXPOSURE TO HEAT
HeatStrokeUnConcious.subtitle: MANAGEMENT IF UNCONSCIOUS
HeatStrokeUnConcious.sym2: Cool using ice packs under the armpits, groin and back of neck. If ice is unavailable pour cold water over patient and wrap in wet sheets or towels
HeatStrokeUnConcious.sym3: Fan them with watever is available; electric fan, towel, newspaper
HeatStrokeUnConcious.sym4: Call an Ambulance or medical assistance urgently
HeatStrokeUnConcious.sym5: Clear the airway and follow the :

Hyperthermiacons.title: EXPOSURE TO HEAT
Hyperthermiacons.subtitle: HYPERTHERMIA
Hyperthermiacons.sym1: Lie the patient down in a cool, shaded area
Hyperthermiacons.sym2: Give the patient sips of a solution that is 1/2 a teaspoon of salt in 500ml of water
Hyperthermiacons.sym4: If the patient has experienced severe vomiting or diarrhoea seek urgent medical assistance. Call an Ambulance

HyperthermiaUncons.subtitle: MANAGEMENT IF UNCONSCIOUS
HyperthermiaUncons.sym1: Lie the patient down in a cool, shaded area

Management.title: Management:
Management.point1: Reassure the patient, help into a comfortable position, and minimise their movement.
Management.point2: Call an ambulance if the injured area is clearly deformed, painful,or transport is needed
Management.description: Immobillise by strapping above and below the break using bandages and a splint or sling.Check circulation and monitor frequently; watching exremities(fingers and toes) for loss of circukation (loss of skin colour)
Management.des1: Immobilise a finger or toe with a splint or taping / strapping to another
Management.des2: A leg can be immobilised by strapping to the other leg

ForiegnBodyeye.title: FOREIGN BODY IN EYE
ForiegnBodyeye.point1: Wash the eye from bridge of the nose outwards
ForiegnBodyeye.point2: Always angle the injured eye downwards to prevent spill into the other eye
ForiegnBodyeye.point3: Embedded objects must only be removed by medical staff
ForiegnBodyeye.point4: Closed eye injuries must only be treated by trained medical staff
ForiegnBodyeye.point5: Dress with care using an eye pad or No.13 wound dressing, by placing the combined dressing pad on the eye and gently strapping around the patient's head.
ForiegnBodyeye.point6: NOTE: A person wearing an eye pad should not drive a vehicle.

HeadInjury.title: HEAD INJURY
HeadInjury.description: Even if the patient has been unconscious only for a short time they must always be seen by a doctor
HeadInjury.des1: Patient with a head injury should be treated as having a spinal injury until proven otherwise

History.title: History
History.description: Look for evidence that suggests a head injury, for example fallen objects, ask the patient or bystander about what happened

symptoms.sym1: May take up to a couple of days to develop.
symptoms.sym2: Common symptoms include headache, dizziness, drowsiness, confusion, blurred vision, and nausea.

conscious.cons1: Position the patient on their back with their head and shoulders slightly raised.

unconscious.uncon1: If unconscious, clear the airway and follow the DRSABCD action plan.
unconscious.uncon2: If the person becomes confused, drowsy, vomits, experiences blurred vision, or has other concerning symptoms, call an ambulance.

symptoms.sym1: Tight or heavy pain across the chest.
symptoms.description: Not all patients experience all of these signs and symptoms. If the patient experiences any of these signs or symptoms please seek urgent medical advice.
symptoms.des1: The greatest cause of death in Australia is from heart attack or a sudden collapse due to rhythm disturbances may lead to a cardiac arrest.

conscious.title: HEART ATTACK
conscious.subtitle: MANAGEMENT IF CONSCIOUS
conscious.sym2: Rest and relax the patient, give reassurance
conscious.sym6: If oxygen is available, and you are trained in its use, administer with an oxygen mask, until an ambulance arrives.

Meningitis.title: MENINGITIS
Meningitis.description: Meningitis is a potentially life threatening condition.

symptoms.sym1: Stiff painful neck, pain in back and muscles
symptoms.sym2: Whole body: fever, chills, lethargy, loss of appetite, malaise, shivering
symptoms.sym5: Other: irritable, confusion, sensitivity to light, bulging fontanelle, fast breathing, fast heart rate, fear of loud sounds, headache, lack of interest in feeding in infants, sleepiness, sluggishness, or stiff back

conscious.cons1: Position the patient on their back with their head and shoulders slightly raised.

unconscious.uncon1: Call an ambulance or medical assistance urgently.
unconscious.uncon2: Clear the airway and follow the Basic Life Support chart.

symptoms.sym1: Hygiene is always the number one priority for treatmenting all minor wounds. Antiseptic solution should be used and diluted in accordance with instructions. If there is no antiseptic then use saline. Always clean from the centre of the wound outwards and then the patient and constantly observe making a note of comments about their feelings.
symptoms.sym2: Non-adherent dressings are best used for grazes, non blood flow or burns. Always secure the dressing with a conforming bandages or paper tape. Be gentle with the patient, observe. Note: Older people may take Aspirin to thin their blood and can bleed very fast.
symptoms.sym3: Wound dressings are best for blood flowing wounds and also work well on an eye injury. They include a combined dressing with conforming bandage. Always directly on wound and secure.
symptoms.sym4: Triangular Bandages are in every First Aid Kit and are made to become arm slings but are great for padding or strapping legs or arms. Broken collarbones may require three.
symptoms.sym5: Heavy Crepe 10cm, the size of the fist so it csn be applied at the correct pressure without creasing.

Seizures.title: SEIZURES
Seizures.description: Seizures result in the patient falling on the floor and suffering rigid and jerking muscle spasms.

Management.title: Management
Management.sym2: Protect the patient from injury by removing dangerous objects or padding of all surrounding objects
Management.sym3: If biting of the tongue occurs, never place objects into the patient's mouth as it may result in injury to their jaw or teeth as well as potentially blocking their airway.
Management.sym4: When fitting stops, place the patient into the:
Management.des3: When patient regains memory they may be very embarrassed. Therefore, ask bystanders to leave before this occurs and five reassurance to the patient as described in the:
Management.des4: WARNING: Should another fit occur, treat as above and seek urgent medical assistance

symptoms.sym1: If the patient responsive and breathing normally then lie them in their back and raise their legs, (as picture below)
symptoms.sym2: If the patient is Unresponsive and not breathing normally then commence.

Information.sym8: The recognition and prompt management of Shock can drastically reduce a patient's chance of deterioration

Poisons.title: POISONS
Poisons.Description: Always consult the M.S.D.S (Material Safety Data Sheet) and / or call the national poisons information centre on 131126.
Poisons.subtitle: POISONS 24 HOUR CALL LINE:
Poisons.des1: DO NOT give the patient anything to eat or drink unless directed to do so by the MSDS poisons information centre.

conscious.title: POISONS
conscious.cons2: Identify poison, time and route of exposure
conscious.cons3: Remove poison where possible without exposing yourself

unconscious.uncon1: Avoid rescue breaths if there is a risk of cross contamination
